text: Role of ascorbate in the activation of NF-kappaB by <extra_id_0> tumour necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in T-cells .

The first product of ascorbate oxidation , the ascorbate free radical ( AFR ) , acts in biological systems mainly as an oxidant , and through its role in the plasma membrane redox system exerts different effects on the cell .

We have investigated the role of ascorbate , AFR and dehydroascorbate ( DHA ) in the activation of the NF-kappaB transcription factor in Jurkat T-cells stimulated by <extra_id_0> tumour necrosis factor-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) .

Here we show , by electrophoretic mobility shift assays , that ascorbate increases the binding of NF-kappaB to DNA in <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - stimulated Jurkat cells .

The ability of ascorbate to enhance cytoplasmic inhibitory <extra_id_0> IkBalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> protein degradation correlates completely with its capacity to induce NF-kappaB binding to DNA and to potentiate NF-kappaB - mediated transactivation of the HIV-1 long terminal repeat promoter in <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - stimulated Jurkat cells but not in cells stimulated with PMA plus ionomycin .

text: AFR behaves like ascorbate , while DHA and ascorbate phosphate do not affect <extra_id_0> TNF-alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> - mediated NF-kappaB activation .

These results provide new evidence for a possible relationship between the activation of the electron-transport system at the plasma membrane by ascorbate or its free radical and redox - dependent gene transcription in T-cells .
